lessons.title: Understanding ADHD
lessons.subtitle: The truth about ADHD that most people get wrong

sections.content: Hey {name}! I'm so glad you're here. ADHD coaching is one of the most impactful specialties you can pursue. Millions of adults and children struggle with ADHD, and most of them aren't getting the support they need. By the end of this training, you'll understand how to really help them. Let's dive in.
What ADHD Really Is

ADHD isn't a character flaw, a discipline problem, or something people can just 'try harder' to overcome. It's a neurodevelopmental condition that affects the brain's executive functions - the mental processes that help us plan, focus, remember, and regulate our behavior.

ADHD is not a deficit of attention - it's a problem with regulating attention. People with ADHD can often hyperfocus intensely on things they find interesting while struggling to focus on 'boring' but necessary tasks. This is why the name 'Attention Deficit' is actually misleading.
The Three Types of ADHD
ADHD presents differently in different people:
items: Predominantly Inattentive - Difficulty focusing, easily distracted, forgetful, loses things
Predominantly Hyperactive-Impulsive - Restless, fidgety, interrupts, acts without thinking
Combined Type - Shows symptoms of both inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity

sections.content: The Hidden Epidemic

ADHD affects about 4-5% of adults worldwide - that's over 300 million people. Yet only about 20% of adults with ADHD have been diagnosed. Many went through life being called 'lazy,' 'careless,' or 'not living up to their potential.'
Why ADHD coaching is desperately needed:
items: Most therapists and doctors focus on medication, not practical strategies
Adults with ADHD often struggle despite being highly intelligent
ADHD coaching focuses on skills, systems, and practical solutions
Coaching provides the accountability and structure ADHD brains crave
The coaching industry for ADHD is growing 25%+ annually

sections.content: I was diagnosed at 42 after a lifetime of feeling like I was broken. Now I coach other adults who got late diagnoses. Helping them realize they're not lazy or stupid - just wired differently - is the most rewarding work I've ever done. - Marcus T., ADHD Coach
Why YOU Are Called to This
Many ADHD coaches have ADHD themselves or have close family members with it. Your lived experience isn't a weakness - it's your greatest asset. You understand the struggles from the inside.

ADHD coaching isn't about 'fixing' people - it's about helping them leverage their unique brain wiring. Many of history's most creative, innovative people had ADHD. Your job is to help clients find their superpowers while managing their challenges.
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll explore the ADHD brain in detail - what's actually happening neurologically and why traditional advice often fails people with ADHD.

keyTakeaways: ADHD is a neurodevelopmental condition, not a character flaw
It affects attention regulation, not just attention deficit
Over 300 million adults worldwide have ADHD, most undiagnosed
ADHD coaching is a rapidly growing field with massive demand
Your personal connection to ADHD is an asset, not a liability

lessons.title: The ADHD Brain
lessons.subtitle: Understanding the neuroscience behind ADHD

sections.content: Welcome back, {name}! Now that you understand what ADHD is, let's explore the ADHD brain. Understanding the neuroscience helps you explain to clients why they struggle with certain things and why traditional advice often doesn't work for them.
The Dopamine Connection

ADHD brains have lower baseline levels of dopamine and norepinephrine - neurotransmitters that regulate attention, motivation, and reward. This isn't a minor difference; it fundamentally changes how ADHD brains experience motivation and focus.

The ADHD brain is constantly seeking stimulation because of dopamine dysregulation. This is why boring tasks feel almost physically painful, while highly stimulating activities can produce intense hyperfocus. The brain is desperately trying to get the dopamine it needs.
The Prefrontal Cortex
The prefrontal cortex - the brain's 'CEO' - develops differently in people with ADHD. This area controls executive functions like planning, impulse control, working memory, and emotional regulation.
Executive function challenges in ADHD:
items: Working Memory - Holding information while using it
Time Blindness - Difficulty sensing the passage of time
Task Initiation - Trouble starting tasks, even important ones
Emotional Regulation - Intense emotions that feel overwhelming
Cognitive Flexibility - Getting stuck on ideas or tasks
Organization - Keeping track of things, materials, schedules

sections.content: Why Traditional Advice Fails
Most productivity advice is designed for neurotypical brains. When people with ADHD try these methods and fail, they feel broken. They're not broken - they're using the wrong tools.
Why common advice doesn't work for ADHD:
items: 'Just focus harder' - ADHD isn't a willpower problem
'Use a planner' - Without proper systems, planners get abandoned
'Set reminders' - ADHD brains often ignore reminders
'Break it into small steps' - Can still feel overwhelming without structure
'Reward yourself after' - Delayed rewards don't motivate ADHD brains

sections.content: As a coach, part of your job is helping clients grieve the neurotypical strategies that never worked for them while discovering ADHD-friendly alternatives that actually do.
ADHD Superpowers
Strengths that often come with ADHD:
items: Creativity and out-of-the-box thinking
Hyperfocus when engaged in interesting work
Crisis performance - thriving under pressure
Energy and enthusiasm that inspires others
Pattern recognition and connecting disparate ideas
Resilience from overcoming daily challenges

sections.content: Once I understood my brain, everything changed. I stopped trying to fit into a neurotypical mold and started designing a life that worked with my ADHD, not against it. Now I help others do the same. - Jennifer K., ADHD Coach
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll dive deep into executive function and self-regulation - the core struggles that ADHD coaching addresses.

keyTakeaways: ADHD involves dopamine and norepinephrine dysregulation
The prefrontal cortex develops differently, affecting executive functions
Traditional productivity advice fails because it's designed for neurotypical brains
ADHD comes with genuine superpowers alongside its challenges
Understanding the brain helps clients stop blaming themselves

lessons.title: Executive Function & Self-Regulation
lessons.subtitle: The core struggles that ADHD coaching addresses

sections.content: {name}, this lesson covers the heart of ADHD struggles - executive function deficits. Understanding these deeply will make you an effective coach. These are the specific areas where your clients need the most support.
What Are Executive Functions?

Executive functions are the brain's management system. Think of them as the mental processes that help us organize, plan, initiate, and complete tasks. For people with ADHD, these functions are impaired - not absent, but inconsistent and unreliable.

ADHD executive function deficits are often invisible. Clients may appear to be capable of doing something (and sometimes they are), which is why others assume they're just lazy or unmotivated when they can't. This inconsistency is a hallmark of ADHD.
The Seven Executive Functions
Core areas affected by ADHD:
items: Self-Awareness - Monitoring thoughts and actions
Inhibition - Stopping before acting impulsively
Non-Verbal Working Memory - Holding images and concepts in mind
Verbal Working Memory - Self-talk and internal dialogue
Emotional Regulation - Managing feelings appropriately
Self-Motivation - Doing things without external rewards
Planning & Problem Solving - Breaking down goals into steps

sections.content: Time Blindness

One of the most misunderstood ADHD challenges is 'time blindness.' People with ADHD often have a genuinely different experience of time - it can feel elastic, where hours pass like minutes or minutes feel like hours.
How time blindness shows up:
items: Chronic lateness despite best intentions
Underestimating how long tasks will take
Missing deadlines that 'sneak up' on them
Difficulty understanding 'later' - only now and not now
Procrastinating because the deadline feels far away

sections.content: Time blindness isn't a choice or a sign of disrespect. Helping clients externalize time (clocks everywhere, timers, time-blocking) is one of the most practical interventions you can offer.
Emotional Dysregulation

ADHD brains feel emotions more intensely and have trouble regulating them. Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD) - extreme emotional sensitivity to perceived criticism or rejection - affects up to 99% of people with ADHD.
Signs of ADHD emotional challenges:
items: Intense reactions to minor frustrations
Overwhelming feelings when facing criticism
Quick-shifting emotions that feel out of control
Difficulty letting go of emotional experiences
People-pleasing to avoid potential rejection

sections.content: I used to think I was just 'too sensitive.' Learning about RSD was life-changing. Now I help clients recognize these patterns and develop coping strategies that actually work. - Amanda R., ADHD Coach
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll cover practical time management and organization strategies specifically designed for ADHD brains.

keyTakeaways: Executive functions are the brain's management system
ADHD causes inconsistent, not absent, executive function
Time blindness is a real neurological difference, not a choice
Emotional dysregulation (including RSD) affects nearly all with ADHD
Understanding these functions helps target coaching interventions

lessons.title: Time Management & Organization
lessons.subtitle: ADHD-friendly systems that actually work

sections.content: {name}, now we get into the practical stuff. Time management and organization are major pain points for people with ADHD. The strategies in this lesson are specifically designed for how ADHD brains actually work - not neurotypical approaches that set them up for failure.
Why Traditional Time Management Fails

Most productivity systems assume a brain that can self-motivate, estimate time accurately, and delay gratification. ADHD brains don't work this way. We need external structure, immediate feedback, and systems that work WITH our brain, not against it.

The best ADHD systems externalize what other brains internalize. If the brain can't do something internally (like track time), we put it outside the brain (visual timers, clocks everywhere). This isn't cheating - it's accommodation.
Time Management Strategies
ADHD-friendly time techniques:
items: Body Doubling - Working alongside someone else (even virtually) for accountability
Time Boxing - Assigning fixed time blocks to tasks, not 'until done'
Visual Timers - Making time visible (Time Timer, hourglass)
Calendar Blocking - Only what's on the calendar is real
Buffer Time - Always add 50% more time than you think you need
Artificial Deadlines - Creating urgency before the real deadline

sections.content: The Power of External Structure

ADHD brains thrive with external structure - a boss waiting, an appointment, a study group. Without this structure, tasks can feel optional. Coaching provides exactly this kind of external accountability.
Creating external structure:
items: Accountability partners who check in regularly
Public commitments that create social stakes
Coaching sessions that review progress
Body doubling sessions for difficult tasks
Apps that block distractions externally

sections.content: Many clients feel shame about needing external structure. Help them reframe: this isn't weakness, it's wisdom. Using tools and supports is exactly what ADHD brains need to function.
Organization Systems
ADHD-friendly organization principles:
items: Out of Sight = Out of Mind - Use clear containers and visible storage
One-Touch Rule - Put things away immediately, not 'later'
Landing Zones - Designated spots for keys, wallet, phone
Simple Categories - Fewer categories, broader buckets
Regular Resets - Weekly 'organization sessions' to prevent chaos
Good Enough - Perfect organization isn't the goal; functional is

sections.content: I tried every productivity system and failed. My coach helped me build a simple system that actually worked for MY brain. Now I teach those same principles to my clients. The key is customization, not copying what works for neurotypical people. - James L., ADHD Coach
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll tackle emotional regulation strategies - helping clients manage the intense feelings that come with ADHD.

keyTakeaways: Traditional productivity systems often fail ADHD brains
Externalize what neurotypical brains internalize
Body doubling and accountability are powerful ADHD tools
Simple systems beat complex ones for ADHD
Coaching provides the external structure ADHD brains need

lessons.title: Emotional Regulation Strategies
lessons.subtitle: Managing the intense emotions of ADHD

sections.content: {name}, emotional dysregulation is often the hidden struggle of ADHD. While time management gets the attention, many clients struggle most with their emotions - the overwhelming feelings, the sensitivity to rejection, the frustration that boils over. This lesson gives you tools to help.
ADHD and Emotions

ADHD brains feel emotions more intensely and have trouble regulating them. This isn't a character flaw - it's neurological. The same prefrontal cortex issues that affect attention also affect emotional control.

ADHD emotions are like a car with a powerful engine but worn brakes. The feelings are intense (powerful engine) but the ability to slow them down is compromised (worn brakes). Understanding this helps clients stop blaming themselves.
Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD)
RSD is extreme emotional sensitivity to perceived rejection or criticism. It affects up to 99% of people with ADHD and can be one of the most impairing aspects of the condition.
Signs of RSD:
items: Devastating reaction to minor criticism
Fear of rejection that limits taking risks
People-pleasing to avoid any possibility of rejection
Interpreting neutral feedback as negative
Withdrawing before others can reject them
Replaying perceived slights for days or longer

sections.content: Emotional Regulation Techniques
Strategies that help ADHD emotions:
items: Naming the Emotion - 'I'm feeling rejected' reduces intensity
HALT Check - Am I Hungry, Angry, Lonely, Tired?
Time Delay - Wait before responding (the 24-hour rule)
Physical Movement - Exercise regulates emotion chemically
Grounding Techniques - 5-4-3-2-1 sensory awareness
Self-Compassion - Treating yourself as you would a friend

sections.content: Help clients create 'RSD first aid' plans - specific strategies they can use when they feel rejection hitting. Having a plan before the emotion hits is much more effective than trying to think clearly during it.
The Emotional Flood

When ADHD emotions get overwhelming, the brain can enter a 'flood' state where higher reasoning goes offline. Trying to problem-solve during a flood is futile. The goal is to return to baseline first.
During emotional floods:
items: Recognition - 'I'm flooded right now'
Pause - Don't make decisions or send messages
Move - Physical movement helps reset the nervous system
Time - Wait until the intensity passes (usually 20-30 minutes)
Then problem-solve - Only address the issue when calm

sections.content: Learning about RSD explained my whole life. I wasn't 'too sensitive' - my brain was wired this way. Now I help clients give themselves the same grace. Understanding is the first step to managing it. - Nicole P., ADHD Coach
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll cover building habits that stick - why traditional habit advice fails ADHD brains and what to do instead.

keyTakeaways: ADHD emotional dysregulation is neurological, not a character flaw
RSD affects nearly all people with ADHD and can be severely impairing
Naming emotions and having a plan reduces their intensity
During emotional floods, the goal is to calm down before problem-solving
Self-compassion is essential for ADHD emotional management

lessons.title: Building Habits That Stick
lessons.subtitle: ADHD-friendly approaches to lasting change

sections.content: {name}, building habits is notoriously difficult for people with ADHD. They've probably failed at habit-building a hundred times using neurotypical advice. This lesson shows you how to help clients create habits that actually stick for ADHD brains.
Why Habits Are Hard for ADHD

Neurotypical brains create habits through repetition until behaviors become automatic. ADHD brains have trouble with this automation. Behaviors that should become automatic often stay effortful indefinitely.

ADHD brains may never fully automate certain behaviors. This means they'll need ongoing external support (reminders, cues, accountability) for habits that neurotypical people do without thinking. This isn't failure - it's adaptation.
ADHD Habit Principles
What works for ADHD habits:
items: Novelty - ADHD brains need variety; rotate HOW you do habits
Immediacy - The reward must come immediately, not later
External Cues - Visual reminders, alarms, environmental triggers
Tiny Steps - Ridiculously small steps that feel almost too easy
Gamification - Make it a game with points, streaks, rewards
Flexibility - Build in 'good enough' versions for hard days

sections.content: The Habit Stacking Method

Habit stacking links a new habit to an existing behavior. 'After I [existing habit], I will [new habit].' This uses the existing behavior as a cue, which is more reliable than trying to remember the new habit.
Examples of habit stacking:
items: After I pour my coffee, I will take my medication
After I sit on the couch at night, I will set out clothes for tomorrow
After I park my car, I will do a 30-second car cleanup
After I brush my teeth, I will floss one tooth
After finishing a task, I will do a 2-minute email check

sections.content: The 'one tooth floss' approach is powerful for ADHD. Starting is the hardest part - once they floss one tooth, they usually do more. The goal is to make starting so easy that the brain doesn't resist.
When Habits Fail
ADHD clients will break streaks and miss days. The goal isn't perfect consistency - it's building resilience to restart. 'Never miss twice' is more realistic than 'never miss.'
Habit recovery strategies:
items: Expect breaks - Plan for them, don't be shocked by them
Restart immediately - The longer the gap, the harder to restart
No shame spiral - Self-criticism makes restarting harder
Analyze what happened - Curiosity, not judgment
Adjust the system - Maybe it needs to be easier or different

sections.content: I'd tried every habit app and failed. My coach taught me to expect breaks and restart without shame. Now I've maintained an exercise habit for 3 years - not perfectly, but consistently enough. That's a miracle for me. - David W., Coaching Client
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll cover coaching adults with ADHD - specific considerations for working with adult clients.

keyTakeaways: ADHD brains may never fully automate habits like neurotypical brains
Novelty, immediacy, and external cues are essential for ADHD habits
Habit stacking uses existing behaviors as anchors for new ones
Start ridiculously small - the key is reducing resistance to starting
Expect breaks and build resilience to restart without shame

lessons.title: Coaching Adults with ADHD
lessons.subtitle: Specific strategies for working with adult clients

sections.content: {name}, adult ADHD presents unique challenges. Many adults weren't diagnosed until later in life and carry decades of shame and coping strategies (both healthy and unhealthy). This lesson covers how to effectively coach adult clients with ADHD.
The Late-Diagnosed Adult
Many adults with ADHD weren't diagnosed until their 30s, 40s, or later. They may have spent decades thinking they were lazy, stupid, or broken. A late diagnosis can bring both relief and grief.

Late diagnosis often brings grief - for the years of struggle, the opportunities missed, the relationships damaged. Allow clients space to process this loss while also embracing the relief that understanding brings.
Common Adult ADHD Struggles
Issues adult clients often face:
items: Career underperformance despite intelligence
Relationship problems from forgetfulness or emotional dysregulation
Financial difficulties from impulse spending or disorganization
Low self-esteem from years of 'failures'
Burnout from masking and overcompensating
Anxiety/depression that developed alongside undiagnosed ADHD

sections.content: Coaching Approaches for Adults
What works with adult ADHD clients:
items: Education First - Help them understand their brain before building strategies
Validate Their Experience - Acknowledge the real struggles they've faced
Build on Strengths - What's already working? Do more of that
Customize Strategies - No one-size-fits-all; test and iterate
Short-Term Focus - Break goals into 2-4 week experiments
Regular Check-Ins - More frequent contact keeps momentum

sections.content: Adults with ADHD often have highly developed coping mechanisms. Some are healthy (using technology well), some are unhealthy (avoidance, perfectionism). Part of coaching is preserving what works and replacing what doesn't.
Life Areas to Address
Key coaching topics for adults:
items: Career - Finding ADHD-friendly careers or adapting current roles
Relationships - Communication, expectations, getting support
Finances - Systems for money management
Health - Exercise, sleep, medication management
Self-Care - Managing burnout and building resilience
Identity - Reframing the ADHD narrative from deficit to difference

sections.content: Being diagnosed at 45 was overwhelming. My coach helped me grieve the lost years while building a future that works with my brain. I'm more successful now than I ever was trying to be 'normal.' - Sarah M., Coaching Client
Coming Up Next
In the next lesson, we'll cover working with parents of ADHD kids - a different but equally important coaching specialty.

keyTakeaways: Late-diagnosed adults often need time to process grief alongside relief
Years of 'failure' create self-esteem challenges that need addressing
Adult ADHD affects relationships, career, finances, and health
Customize strategies - what works for one client may not work for another
Regular check-ins maintain momentum and provide accountability

lessons.title: Working with Parents of ADHD Kids
lessons.subtitle: Coaching families affected by ADHD

sections.content: {name}, many ADHD coaches work with parents of children with ADHD. These parents are often overwhelmed, exhausted, and desperate for strategies. This lesson shows you how to support them effectively - without overstepping your scope into therapy.
The ADHD Parent Experience

Parents of kids with ADHD face daily challenges that can be exhausting. They're often judged by others who think the child just needs more discipline. They worry about their child's future and feel guilty about their own frustration.

Many parents of ADHD kids also have ADHD themselves (it's highly genetic). They may be struggling with their own executive functions while trying to support a child who struggles too. This isn't weakness - it's biology.
What Parents Need
Core parent coaching areas:
items: Understanding - Learning how ADHD affects their specific child
Strategies - Practical tools for daily challenges
Advocacy - How to work with schools and doctors
Self-Care - Managing their own wellbeing (crucial!)
Relationship - Strengthening the parent-child bond
Hope - Envisioning a positive future for their child

sections.content: Parenting Strategy Shifts
Key mindset changes for parents:
items: From punishment to teaching - ADHD kids need skill-building, not consequences
From 'won't' to 'can't' - Many behaviors are inability, not defiance
From comparison to individual - Their child's path will look different
From controlling to scaffolding - Build external supports gradually
From fixing to accepting - The goal is thriving with ADHD, not 'curing' it
From exhaustion to boundaries - Parents need rest to be effective

sections.content: Parent coaching is distinct from child therapy. You coach the parent on strategies, communication, and self-care. If the child needs direct intervention, refer to a qualified child therapist or ADHD specialist.
Practical Parent Strategies
Tools to teach parents:
items: Visual schedules and routines
Positive reinforcement systems
Environmental modifications
Communication techniques for ADHD kids
Homework and school support strategies
Managing sibling dynamics
Collaborating effectively with schools

sections.content: I was drowning before coaching. My son's ADHD was running our whole family. Learning strategies AND taking care of myself changed everything. Now I can actually help him instead of just reacting. - Maria L., Parent Coaching Client
Coming Up Next
In our final lesson, we'll cover launching your ADHD coaching practice - practical steps to start serving clients.

keyTakeaways: Parents of ADHD kids face daily challenges that require ongoing support
Many parents of ADHD children have ADHD themselves
Key shifts include moving from punishment to teaching, 'won't' to 'can't'
Parent coaching focuses on the parent - refer kids for direct intervention
Parent self-care is essential, not optional

sections.content: The ADHD Coaching Market
ADHD coaching is one of the fastest-growing coaching specialties. With more adults being diagnosed than ever before and parents desperate for support, the demand far outstrips supply.

ADHD coaches typically charge $150-300 per session and often have waitlists. The niche is specific enough to attract clients but broad enough to build a full practice. Many ADHD coaches work exclusively with this population.
Getting Started
First steps to launch:
items: Define your ideal client - Adults? Parents? Both?
Create simple offers - Start with 1-1 coaching packages
Build visibility - Share ADHD content on social media
Connect with referrers - Therapists, doctors, ADHD communities
Get testimonials - Offer reduced rates for your first clients
Consider certification - Our full program provides deeper training

sections.content: Your Certification Path
This mini-diploma gives you a foundation. Our full Board Certification goes much deeper - advanced strategies, supervised practice hours, and the credential that serious clients look for.

You're now qualified to begin helping people with ADHD. The certification you receive today proves your foundational knowledge. Continue to our full program for the complete toolkit and professional credential.
Your ADHD Coaching Future

Imagine working from home, setting your own hours, and spending your days truly helping people transform their lives. ADHD coaching offers all of this - meaningful work with a population that desperately needs what you have to offer.

Starting my ADHD coaching practice was the best decision I ever made. I have ADHD myself, so I truly understand my clients. I make $7K/month working 20 hours a week, and I've never been more fulfilled. You can do this too. - Rebecca K., Certified ADHD Coach
